text: [Music]
I'm Dan Levin to the New York Times
reporting from Guangzhou China and this
is the 11th annual Guangzhou sex culture
festival which took place in
mid-november --zz we're country
notoriously shy about discussing sex in
public the sex festival has become an
incredibly popular opportunity for
Chinese to explore the most private
desires and discover new ones China
makes three-quarters of the world's sex
toys reportedly a multi-billion dollar
business here but they're mostly for
export still it was clear that this
homegrown industry also has a growing
domestic appeal the sex festival was
overrun by men an imbalance that
reflects a demographic crisis in China
where men vastly outnumber women it's
particularly acute here in the southern
manufacturing hub of Guangdong Province
home to China's largest population of
migrant workers visitors were eager to
test out the merchandise and nearly
everyone seemed to want to document the
scene some booths got creative in their
attempts to highlight the importance and
fun of safe sex the first to make their
condom pop in this contest won a cash
prize worth 16 cents strawberry flavored
condoms and a pink battery-operated
device that came in a box labeled let
men enjoy lusty win
[Music]
